questions.text: A South Indian male cattle breeder comes with complaints of frank intermittent epistaxis. The examination of the nose is given below. A biopsy was taken and HPE appears as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rhinosporidiosis Rhinosporidiosisis a granulomatous disease affecting the mucous membrane of nasopharynx, oropharynx, conjunctiva, rectum and external genitalia. It is caused by inoculation into a break of skin or from inhalation of Rhinosporidium seeberi

Highyeild:

Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous disease affecting the mucous membrane of nasopharynx, oropharynx, conjunctiva, rectum and external genitalia. Though the floor of the nose and inferior turbinate are the most common sites, the lesions may appear elsewhere too. History Unilateral nasal obstruction Epistaxis Local pruritus Rhinorrhea Coryza (rhinitis) with sneezing Post nasal discharge with cough Foreign body sensation Increased tearing and photophobia in cases of infection of palpebral conjunctiva On examination Pink to deep red polyps Strawberry like appearance Bleeds easily upon manipulation Diagnosis confirmed by biopsy and histopathology - several round or oval sporangia and spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall Treatment : Surgical excision - wide excision with wide area electro-coagulation of the lesion base. Medical treatment is not so effective but treatment with a year-long course of dapsone has been reported Recurrence is common

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Invasive papilloma: These papillomas are benign but the fact that they can block the nasal passage and become difficult to breathe is very dangerous. Such papilloma must be removed but this should be done under the supervision of the attending physician. Option C. NASAL POLYP : They are noncancerous growths within the nose or sinuses. Symptoms include trouble breathing through the nose, loss of smell, decreased taste, post nasal drip, and a runny nose. Option D. RHINOSCLEROMA: It is a chronic granulomatous bacterial disease of the nose that can sometimes infect the upper respiratory tract. It most commonly affects the nasal cavity

questions.text: identify the nerve block shown in the given image
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nasociliary block The given image shows a nasociliary nerve block. The procedure is done by inserting the needle 1 cm superior and 1.5 cm posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye\

Highyeild:

Regional nerve blocks are useful when tissue distortion from anesthetic volume is to be avoided. They are also useful for patients undergoing more invasive procedures such as dacryocystorhinostomy who are poor candidates for general anesthesia. Nasociliary Nerve Block This nerve branches into the posterior and anterior ethmoidal nerves and the infratrochlear nerve. It innervates the lacrimal sac, inner canthus, and lateral aspect of the nose. To block the infratrochlear nerve, the needle is inserted just above the medial canthal ligament along the medial wall of the orbit to a depth of 1.0 cm. If performing local anesthesia for dacryocystorhinostomy, the anterior ethmoidal nerve with its distal external nasal branch should be blocked using the same procedure but to a depth of 2.0 cm posterior to the anterior lacrimal crest. Nasociliary block is used in Septorhinoplasty Nasal fracture repairs Repair of skin lacerations

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:-

questions.text: A 14-year-old is brought to the OPD with complaints that she is able to hear the sound of speech but has difficulty understanding words. Her PTA and BERA were inconsistent with each other, with PTA being more or less normal. Her middle latency and cortical responses were absent. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Auditory Neuropathy In this clinical scenario, the history of a child presenting with complaints of inability to understand words with abnormal BERA and normal PTA is suggestive of auditory neuropathy.

Highyeild:

Auditory neuropathy/auditory dyssynchrony is a condition that affects the neural processing of auditory stimuli. Pathophysiology: Injury to the synaptic junction between inner hair cells of the cochlea and dendrites of spiral ganglion neurons A.Direct damage to the dendrites of the spiral ganglion neurons B.Direct injury to the spiral ganglion neurons C.Direct axonal damage to the auditory nerve Auditory neuropathy should be suspected in any child with severe speech and language , delayed out of proportion with presumed hearing loss. All of the following must be present in newborns to diagnose auditory neuropathy: Absent or severely abnormal ABR test results at maximal stimulus (100 dBnHL) Normal outer hair cell function as determined by OAEs(Otoacoustic emission) Absent or elevated stapedial reflex thresholds

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Cochlear otosclerosis: Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony . labyrinth in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. Option C. Malingering: Malingering(Non-organic hearing loss).In this type of hearing loss, there is no organic lesion. Usually, there is a motive to claim some compensation for being exposed to industrial noises, head injury, or ototoxic medication. The patient may present with any of the three clinical situations: Total hearing loss in both ears, total loss in only one ear, or exaggerated loss in one or both ears. Option D. Michel’s aplasia: Michel aplasia: There is a complete absence of bone and a membranous labyrinth. Even the petrous apex is absent but external and middle ears may be completely unaffected.The child presents with congenital sensorineural hearing loss. No hearing aids or cochlear implantation can be used.

questions.text: A patient unable to understand words but have normal speech and language, there is discrepancy between PTA and ABR, and there are absent cortical evoked potentials. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Auditory neuropathy In this clinical scenario the history of child presenting with complaints of inability to understand words with abnormal BERA and normal pta is suggestive of auditory neuropathy.

Highyeild:

Auditory neuropathy is a hearing disorder in which the inner ear successfully detects sound, but has a problem with sending sound from the ear to the brain. It can affect people of all ages, from infancy through adulthood Mainly it affects the neural processing of auditory stimuli. Auditory Neuropathy can be diagnosed with a battery of tests including Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE), Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR), and acoustic reflexes . The classic AN paradigm would include present OAEs indicating normal outer hair cell function, absent or abnormal ABR with presence of the cochlear microphonic, and absent acoustic reflexes.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Malingering Tests for malingering: Erhardt’s test and Lombard’s test Option C. Michel aplasia also known as complete labyrinthine aplasia (CLA), is a congenital abnormality of the inner ear. It is characterized by the bilateral absence of differentiated inner ear structures and results in complete deafness (anacusis). Michel aplasia should not be confused with michel dysplasia. Option D. Cochlear otosclerosis is a condition that causes sensorineural hearing loss or mixed-type hearing loss due to the abnormal growth of bone in the inner ear.

questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway Medial Geniculate body Cochlear nuclei Olivary complex Lateral lemniscus Cortex Inferior colliculi Choose the correct answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B,C,D,F,A,E The correct auditory pathway sequence is: Eighth nerve-cochlear nuclei-superior olivary nucleus-lateral lemniscus-inferior colliculus-medial geniculate body-auditory cortex

Highyeild:

The auditory pathway is the neural pathway that carries auditory information (sound signals) from the ears to the brain, where it is processed and interpreted as sound perception. The pathway involves several stages and nuclei within the central nervous system. Here’s a simplified sequence of the auditory pathway: Outer Ear: Sound waves enter the ear and travel through the external auditory canal to reach the eardrum (tympanic membrane). Middle Ear: Sound waves cause the eardrum to vibrate, which, in turn, causes the ossicles (tiny bones) in the middle ear (malleus, incus, and stapes) to vibrate. Inner Ear (Cochlea): Fluid movement within the cochlea stimulates hair cells located in the spiral-shaped organ of Corti. Hair cell stimulation generates electrical signals that are sent along the auditory nerve (cranial nerve VIII) to the brainstem. Cochlear Nucleus (Brainstem): The auditory nerve fibers synapse at the cochlear nucleus in the brainstem. Neurons in the cochlear nucleus process and relay auditory information to higher brain centers. Superior Olivary Complex- Brainstem: Information from both ears is compared and integrated to localize sound sources. This complex is involved in sound localization. Lateral Lemniscus: Auditory signals continue to ascend through the brainstem via the lateral lemniscus, which connects various brainstem nuclei. Inferior Colliculus: The auditory pathway reaches the inferior colliculus in the midbrain. Thisstructure isimportant for further processing of auditory information and routing it to different brain regions. Medial Geniculate Nucleus- Thalamus: From the inferior colliculus, auditory signals are relayed to the thalamus, specifically the medial geniculate nucleus (MGN). Primary Auditory Cortex-Temporal Lobe: Finally, the processed auditory signals are transmitted from the thalamus to the primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe of the cerebral cortex. The primary auditory cortex is responsible for the conscious perception of sound.
